li.a: District Mission, Goals, Core Beliefs & Learner-Centered Principles
Family Learning and Support for Home Network (FLASH)

img.div:
Where learning leads
to a lifetime of opportunities...

li.a: AP, IB, and Dual Enrollment Courses Information
District Mission, Goals, Core Beliefs & Learner-Centered Principles

span.div:
Dear Families,
As you are aware, our school closing has been extended through May 15 with the earliest possible return to be Monday, May 18. We have made some decisions regarding our district events which were scheduled to take place during the months of May and June.
> All art shows, concerts, field trips and the senior high dance recital have been cancelled, along with the Community Music Festival.
Athletics continues to be on hold.
> The high school administrators and advisors are looking at future dates with venues in an attempt to reschedule the Junior Prom and Senior Ball. The Freshman Formal has been cancelled.

>The Fine Arts staff is working with companies to reschedule the high school, grade 5 and CRS musicals to either later in the school year or early summer. Production teams are reaching out to families to determine potential availability.
> The Awards Ceremonies may be held, but in a modified format.

div.br:
We are in the brainstorming phase of finding a way to hold Graduation in a modified format. We will find a way to honor our seniors and have them receive their diploma.
As mentioned in our prior communication, we have been working diligently to develop and finalize grading practices for the fourth marking period. In these unprecedented times of at-home learning, we are truly focused upon implementing equitable grading practices for this school year.

We want to reassure you that our learning continuity and grading plans are aligned with our Core Beliefs:
> Treating each other with mutual respect, dignity and honesty.
> That everyone deserves a welcoming and nurturing environment that fosters positive relationships.
> Everyone learns best when they are engaged in meaningful, active work.
> Everyone needs to take ownership for advancing the learning of themselves and others.
Thank you for your ongoing collaboration with our staff during this time of uncertainty. As we are in the midst of school closure during the COVID-19 pandemic, we are very aware of the impact on everyone, most importantly your children. It is our intention that students are not negatively impacted by having limited or inconsistent access to learning activities and resources. Listed below you will find our Grading Practices for the fourth quarter marking period.
Grading for Elementary Students (K-4) and Middle School Students (5-6)
We recognize that learning from home is a new experience for our students, teachers, and parents. Given the nature of at-home learning, we decided not to grade students and did not provide a third quarter report card. Instead, we asked our teachers to focus upon providing students with feedback specific to literacy and math learning.
Families will receive a narrative for the fourth marking period. The narrative will include a summary of student learning activities provided during the final 15 weeks of school. This includes whether students return to school or continue with at-home learning. In addition, teachers will provide a reflection of strengths and potential areas of growth representing the first 25 weeks of school focusing upon reading, writing and math.
Grading for Middle School Students (7-8) and High School Students (9-12)
Third Quarter marking period
> In order to give students the opportunity to submit owed work and improve their overall grade, students were able to submit classwork through April 17. This may be extended on a case-by-case basis.
> Only credit bearing courses in grades 7 & 8 will receive numeric grades. All other students will receive a P- pass or I-incomplete for the third quarter marking period.
> All 9-12 courses will receive a numeric grade for the third quarter marking period.
> For items students cannot complete due to access to materials or extenuating circumstances, the assignment will be marked “exempt” so that the assignment does not count against the student’s quarter average.
Fourth Quarter marking period and Spring Semester Courses
As we transition from Quarter 3 to Quarter 4, we will shift to a feedback system, numeric scores will not be calculated into a fourth quarter grade. This may include two formats: student work will be coded in Infinite Campus as T-turned in, M- missing, or E-excused or teachers will provide grades with feedback in their Google classroom which will not be averaged into a course grade.
We want students to remain engaged and focus upon learning.

For all courses, including AP and IB, during Quarter 4, students will receive a “Pass” or “Incomplete”. An exception will be Dual Credit Courses which will continue to use traditional grading practices as required by our partner colleges for Quarter 4.
“Pass” indicates the student has been holistically engaged in learning and has provided evidence of meeting minimum course expectations.

“Incomplete” indicates the student is currently unable to meet expectations (due to missing assignments, lack of engagement, lack of access to additional assistance or other extenuating circumstances).
Students and families can monitor the parent portal for outstanding work.

Students not completing assignments or providing enough evidence to determine Pass will be referred to their Assistant Principal to determine appropriate access to materials before determining Incomplete
Infinite Campus Parent Portal may show number grades for assignments; however, they will not be used to calculate an average.

Learning Recovery - now through June 22
Students not on track to earn course credit will have access to credit recovery plans.
Students not recovering their work may result in receiving a “Fail” for the course and scheduled to attend summer school.
Final Exams
The Board of Regents has determined that there will be no Regents exams for the 2019-20 school year. CCCSD will also not be administering local (Non-Regents) finals during the 2019-20 school year.
Final Course Credit
Course credit will be determined by the following:
> Review of first, second and third quarter results, as well as feedback from the fourth quarter student engagement in at-home learning.
> “Pass” indicates a student has holistically been engaged in learning and has provided evidence of meeting minimum course expectations for the school year.
> All “Incompletes” will resolve on June 22 and calculate into a Pass or Fail.
> “Fail” indicates a student has holistically not been engaged in learning and has not provided evidence of meeting minimum course expectations for the school year.
> Students who fail the course will be recommended for summer school or to repeat the course in 2020-21. Summer school courses ending in Regents exams will be exempt from taking the Regents exam as per state guidelines.
How will Regents exam credit be granted? The NYS Board of Regents has established exemptions for the corresponding Regents exam through the following criteria:
> The student is currently enrolled in the course of study culminating in a Regents Exam and by the scheduled date of the June 2020 Regents Examination will have earned credit in such course of study;
> The student is currently enrolled in a course of study culminating in a Regents Examination and has failed to earn credit by the end of the school year. Such student returns for summer instruction to make up the failed course credit and is subsequently granted diploma credit in August 2020; or
> The student was previously enrolled in the course leading to an applicable Regents Examination, has achieved course credit, and has not yet passed the associated Regents Exam but was intending to take the test in June to achieve a passing score.
How will Regents course credit be granted? The student should be granted the diploma credit as long as the student has met the standards assessed in the provided coursework. See the Commissioner's Regulations Department Guidance issued March 13, 2020 for more details.
For information on IB, AP and dual-enrollment courses, please visit this link our district website: https://www.cccsd.org/APIBandDualEnrollmentCoursesInformation.aspx

div.text-node: In closing, thank you for your continued patience and partnership with us as we work through modified grading practices and updated At-home Learning Plans. This is not easy for any of us, but most importantly our children. Please continue to keep your child’s physical and mental well-being, along with your families, as a priority. Take care of yourself and stay healthy.

div.span: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is a respiratory illness that is spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes. It is typically passed between people who are in close contact with one another. Older people and people with severe underlying health conditions (such as heart disease, lung disease, and diabetes) seem to be at a higher risk of developing Coronavirus disease.
